document_title: Growth and Antifungal Resistance of the Pathogenic Yeast, Candida Albicans, in the Microgravity Environment of the International Space Station: An Aggregate of Multiple Flight Experiences
summary_full: This study investigated the cellular and physiological adaptations of Candida albicans, a common opportunistic fungal pathogen, when cultured in microgravity aboard the International Space Station across several missions and using two different bioreactor systems (FPA and FEP bags). The research aimed to understand yeast responses to microgravity for crew safety and to assess biological reproducibility across flight opportunities and hardware. Results indicated that C. albicans generally exhibited a slightly shorter generation time and higher growth propensity in microgravity compared to terrestrial controls. While filamentation rates varied between bioreactors, they were low and not significantly different between flight and ground conditions. A key finding was the increased resistance of yeast to the antifungal agent amphotericin B when challenged during spaceflight, a phenomenon not observed with caspofungin. Colony morphology remained similar between flight and terrestrial samples, contrasting with previous findings in ground-based microgravity analog systems. The study also noted potential cellular adaptations that might compromise membrane integrity, as evidenced by diminished post-flight survival of chilled or frozen cells cultured in microgravity. Overall, yeast cells cultivated in microgravity demonstrated a subset of characteristics associated with virulence, highlighting the importance of understanding these responses for long-duration space missions.
key_findings: Candida albicans showed a trend towards higher growth density and slightly shorter generation times in microgravity compared to terrestrial controls across multiple missions and bioreactor types.
Yeast cultivated in microgravity exhibited increased resistance to the antifungal agent amphotericin B, but not to caspofungin.
Cell filamentation rates were low and not significantly different between microgravity and terrestrial conditions.
Colony morphology of C. albicans grown in microgravity was similar to terrestrial controls, differing from observations in ground-based microgravity analog systems.
Cells cultured in microgravity showed reduced viability when frozen without cryopreservation compared to terrestrial controls, suggesting potential adaptations affecting membrane integrity.
future_research_fields: Investigating the molecular mechanisms behind amphotericin B resistance in microgravity.
Further studies on the integrity of cell membranes and cell walls in microgravity-adapted yeast.
Longer-duration spaceflight experiments to assess biofilm formation and complex colony morphology.
Comparative analysis of different spaceflight hardware systems for culturing microorganisms.
Exploring the impact of microgravity on the expression of virulence-associated genes in C. albicans.

conclusions: Candida albicans exhibits altered growth characteristics and increased resistance to amphotericin B when cultured in microgravity. While filamentation and biofilm formation were not significantly enhanced, the observed changes in antifungal resistance and post-flight viability suggest cellular adaptations that may influence virulence. The study also highlights the importance of comparing different spaceflight hardware and assessing biological reproducibility across missions.
impact_statement: This research provides crucial insights into the behavior of a common human pathogen in microgravity, informing strategies for maintaining astronaut health and safety during long-duration space missions.
